meanings.definition: To pull up by the roots
meanings.sent1: I had to radicate the weeds from my garden to make room for new flowers.
meanings.sent2: The gardener needed to radicate the old tree to plant a new one in its place.
meanings.sent3: Trying to radicate the stubborn weed felt like a never-ending battle.
meanings.sent4: She hoped to radicate the bad habits from her life like pulling out unwanted roots.
meanings.sent5: The task of radicating the invasive plant species was daunting but necessary.

meanings.sent1: The detective had to radicate all evidence of the crime scene to protect the investigation.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to radicate all traces of the old logo from their branding.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to radicate all junk food from his diet lasted only a day.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to radicate any hope of a peaceful evening.
meanings.sent5: The magician's trick was to radicate the selected card from the deck entirely.

meanings.sent1: The superhero's mission was to radicate all evil from the city.
meanings.sent2: The virus spread quickly, and the only solution was to radicate it completely.
meanings.sent3: The chef's goal was to radicate any trace of burnt flavor from the dish.
meanings.sent4: The floodwaters threatened to radicate the small town from the map.
meanings.sent5: The scientist worked tirelessly to radicate the invasive species from the ecosystem.
